reporting-org.narrative: The Uganda Association of Women Lawyers ( FIDA Uganda)

title.narrative: We Cannot Wait

description.narrative:
With support from Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Netherlands), FIDA Uganda is implementing a five-year project, titled We Cannot Wait towards an Inclusive and diverse women Movement in the Greater Horn of Africa. This is a Consortium implementled project headed by SIHA. This project builds on the complementarity of project partners and years of shared experience and goals in the region, to strengthen the women’s movement, advocate for an inclusive and feminist legal framework and link together women’s organizations to push a gender-focused agenda in the region. The project’s long term strategic objective is “Women in the Greater Horn of Africa will be leading and defining the political, sociocultural and economic agenda through a gender lens at all levels.” The specific objectives of the project are; 1. Women’s rights activists and organizations (WRA/Os) are advocating for policy, law reform, and social norms. 2. WRA/Os in GHoA form an inclusive and diverse coalition with shared agendas. 3. WRA/Os engage actively and visibly in existing or new political and social platforms to promote their agendas.
In Uganda, the project is implemented in 4 districts of Gulu, Lira, Pader, and Kampala.

title.narrative: Outcome(O)2: WRA/Os form an inclusive and diverse coalition with shared agendas

# of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions on women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision-making processes in public, private and civic sphere, through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or movement building at Grassroots level

comment.narrative: Most of them women reported having been part of coalitions for shared agenda
We will work within the existing ones and create 10 sub-national level forums for joint action

WOMEN IN THE GREATER HORN OF AFRICA WILL BE LEADING AND DEFINING THE POLITICAL, SOCIOCULTURAL AND ECONOMIC AGENDA THROUGH A GENDER LENS AT ALL LEVELS.
# of laws implemented for sustainable and inclusive development;

comment.narrative: advocate and lobby for amendment of Laws including protecting women's rights to economic or political empowerment including Constitutional requirement for the representation of women in all elected and appointed political positions at all levels, amendment of the Ethiopian Electoral, Political Parties Registration and Election’s Code of Conduct

title.narrative: # of governmental policies implemented for sustainable and inclusive development

Intermediate Outcome (IO): 1.2 WRA/Os are able to propose legal and policy reforms
# international agreements improved to eradicate all forms of violence against women and young women in public and private life

comment.narrative: Although Uganda has ratified most of the international conventions protecting the rights of women and girls including the Convention Against Torture (CAT) and the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC), African Charter on Human and Peoples’ Rights (ACHPR) and Maputo Protocol and is a signatory to the African Union Solemn Declaration on Gender Equality in Africa, gaps in their implementation still persists.

title.narrative: # laws improved to eradicate all forms of violence against women and young women in public and private life

comment.narrative: It has enacted Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) Act 2010; Equal Opportunities Commission Act 2008; Anti-trafficking in persons Act 2008; Domestic Violence Act 2006; and Local Government Act 1997; The government has also facilitated various programs towards women economic and political empowerment, such as UWEP and has made good progress in implementing these.

title.narrative: # governmental policies improved to eradicate all forms of violence against women and young women in public and private life
# private sector company policies improved to eradicate all forms of violence against women and young women in public and private life
# by-laws improved to eradicate all forms of violence against women and young women in public and private life
Intermediate Outcome: 1.1WRA/Os are able to lead and take transformative leadership positions
# of individuals (female) with improved attitudes and practices towards women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision-making processes

comment.narrative: 25/72 reported to have ever participated in political campaigns. Additionally, 10/72 reported to have run for political office; 26/72 women interviewed at baseline reported they are interested in political affairs, 28/72 reported having knowledge on both electoral and governance process and only 27/72 perceive that the political process is fair for women.

Working towards reducing the barriers to women's participation in decision making processes including lack of access to economic opportunities, lack of information on on existing laws that promote women's participation in decision making processes.
